Problem:
Consider a linear system described by the continuous Fourier transform \\( \\hat{f}(\\omega) = \\int_{-\\infty}^{\\infty} f(t) e^{-i\\omega t} dt \\), where \\( f(t) \\) is a time-domain signal. We analyze the impact of a modulation defined by the function \\( g(t) = e^{i\\alpha t} \\) over time t, where \\( \\alpha \\) is a real constant.

If at a certain time \\( t_1 \\), another modulation \\( h(t) = e^{i\\beta t} \\) (where \\( \\beta \\) is a different constant) is applied as an intervention, will the final frequency spectrum \\( \\hat{f}''(\\omega) \\) be a simple superposition of \\( \\alpha \\) and \\( \\beta \\) frequency shifts?
Explanation: Applying another modulation \\( h(t) \\) in sequence to the already modulated signal \\( f'(t) = f(t)e^{i\\alpha t} \\) results in \\( f''(t) = f(t)e^{i(\\alpha+\\beta)t} \\). Therefore, the frequency spectrum will reflect the collective shift, namely \\( \\hat{f}(\\omega - (\\alpha + \\beta)) \\), showing a superposed effect.
